title: The Lamborghini 2020 Huracan Evo Spyder Packs A Lot of Punch in a Little Package
text:
Text size

Lamborghinis seem to bring people together, particularly pearl green, sleek ragtops like the 2020 Huracan Evo Spyder. With the cabin exposed to the sky, it dares onlookers to engage. “Talk to me,” the Spyder purrs—and people do.

Here’s what happened when Penta took out the Evo Spyder for a spin: pedestrians, other drivers, all and sundry felt an urgent need to make friends. Folks ask to swap cars, honk, or whoop. Children wave and smile, instinctively recognizing a thing of beauty. On the Major Deegan Expressway, in New York state, of all places, they graciously let you merge into heavy traffic.

The 2020 Huracan Evo Spyder is an expensive ride, to be sure—$287,000 base price ($365,000 as tested, thanks to 20-inch forged Narvi rims; a “pearl effect” paint job, and carbon skin, among many other bells and whistles). That’s comparable to prices of rival super sports cars in the same power range. For those able to afford it, and who prize a thrilling racing experience off the track, the Evo Spyder packs a lot of punch in a relatively small package. With the top down, the ride lives up to Lambo’s marketing: “open air exhilaration.”

Like its cousin, the Huracan Performante, this two-seater is powered by a 5.2- liter, 640-horsepower, V10 naturally aspirated engine with a bold timbre. Expect to be heard before you’re seen. The Evo sports a seven-speed dual clutch-automatic transmission, which can be toggled at will.

At just under 15 feet long and 6.3 feet wide (excluding side view mirrors), the cabin’s a tight fit. Ground clearance is about five inches, rising to seven inches at the touch of a button. Unless the top is down, getting in and out requires six-footers to have a pliable body.

The Spyder offers Lambo’s traditionally angular, low slung, and aggressive body styling, cherished by gearheads the world over. The chassis and shell are made of aluminum, carbon fiber, and composite materials to keep the weight down and your speed up.

The 2020 Huracan Evo Spyder's interior. Lamborghini

Lambo markets this rocket as a tamer, street version of the Performante, but that’s like calling a cougar a housebroken lion. There are differences: The Performante is more aggressive in body style and aerodynamics, with a rear spoiler for downforce on the track. In the Evo Spyder, air is channeled through the hood to create downforce.

The latter also has a touchpad computer console system for cabin and engine controls that is user friendly—not always the case in such cars—which Performante doesn’t. Exclusive to the Evo Spyder is the Lamborghini Dinamica Veicolo Integrata, a CPU that integrates and controls every aspect of the car’s set-up and dynamic behavior, such as acceleration, all wheel-drive, and—also unique—the rear-wheel-steering system, for stability control and better agility.

At low speeds, the rear wheels automatically turn in counter force to the front, up to three degrees left or right. At high speeds, they turn the same as the front wheels for better fast cornering on the way to the grocery store.

The driver can choose from three modes: Strada (street), Sport, and Corsa (track), the high-performance setting where torque delivery changes to 40/60 front back wheels from 20/80 in Strada. The steering and suspension tighten up appreciably, and there’s much less roll on fast turns. The dashboard miles per hour indicator always reads triple digits—to remind you of what the car can do.

The mode change to Corsa is tactile and aural: The engine goes from a smooth, loud purr to a deep, rolling growl. The specs say it does 0 to 62 miles per hour in 2.9 seconds, like the Performante. At 150 mph, it breathed confidence, as if it were just getting started.

Then there’s the soft top. While there’s something magical about any convertible, pushing the limits in the Evo on a bucolic and curvy country road will require your entire attention and driving skills, and is all the more fun for it. As for nature watching, leave that to your intrepid passenger.

Here’s what’s not to like about the Evo: Visibility is minimal out the back “window” and when merging to the right. As for ease of use, the generally well-organized steering wheel has poorly placed cruise controls. Finally, the windshield roof line obstructs the sightline above the car. Though mitigated with the top down, a tall driver might need to bend forward to see things high up, like a traffic light.

Admittedly, any car this expensive is impractical (13-15 miles per gallon), and this one isn’t made for long drives without breaks—your love handles will hurt—but it’s still a joy ride in short spurts.When the Evo Spyder arrives, the welcome is what you might expect if Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni both rolled into town.
description: The two-seat sports car, which starts at $287,000, turns a lot of heads
